PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIAN, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Earnings including Coles, Flight Centre, Nine Entertainment, Origin Energy, Qantas, Qube, Santos, South32 and Vocus
content:
AUSTRALIA

Coca-Cola Amatil (CCL AT) - Co. H1 net AUD 168.0mln vs. Prev. AUD 158.1mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 2.43bln vs. Prev. AUD 2.31bln Y/Y, declares special dividend of AUD 0.04/Shr. (Newswires)

Coles (COL AT) - Co. FY19 net fell 9.1% Y/Y to AUD 1.43bln, rev. AUD 1.89bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.88bln Y/Y, declares special dividend of AUD 0.115/Shr. (Newswires)

ERM Power (EPW AT) - Co. FY19 underlying net AUD 26.0mln vs. Exp. AUD 30.0mln, rev. AUD 3.20bln vs. Prev. AUD 3.28bln Y/Y, Co. received offer from Shell valued at AUD 2.465/Shr vs. last close AUD 1.72/Shr. (Newswires)

Flight Centre (FLT AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 263.8mln vs. Prev. AUD 263.6mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 3.1bln vs. Prev. AUD 2.9bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Lynas (LYC AT) - Co. confirmed its operating licence was renewed in Malaysia. (Newswires)

Medibank (MPL AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 458.7mln vs. Prev. AUD 445.1mln Y/Y, declares special dividend AUD 0.025/Shr. (Newswires)

Mineral Resources (MIN AT) - Co. FY19 normalized net AUD 205mln vs. Exp. AUD 174mln, rev. fell 7% Y/Y to AUD 1.51bln. (Newswires)

Nine Entertainment (NEC AT) - Co. FY19 net rose 6% Y/Y to AUD 221.2mln, rev. AUD 1.85bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.32bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Origin Energy (ORG AT) - Co. FY19 underlying net AUD 1.21bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.02bln Y/Y, rev. AUD 14.7bln vs. Prev. AUD 14.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Perpetual (PPT AT) - Co. FY19 underlying net AUD 115.9mln vs. Exp. AUD 119.8mln. (Newswires)

Qantas (QAN AT) - Co. FY19 underlying pretax profit AUD 1.30bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.60bln Y/Y, rev. AUD 17.96bln vs. Prev. AUD 17.10bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Qube Holdings (QUB AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 196.6mln vs. Prev. AUD 199.3mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 1.84bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.77bln Y/Y, declares special dividend of AUD 0.01/Shr. (Newswires)

Reject Shop (TRS AT) - Co. FY19 EBITDA fell 57.6% Y/Y to AUD 18.2mln, rev. AUD 793.7mln vs. Exp. AUD 787.0mln. (Newswires)

Ruralco (RHL AT) - ACCC will not oppose Co. acquisition by Nutrien (NTR). (Newswires)

Santos (STO AT) - Co. H1 net AUD 388mln vs. Prev. AUD 104mln Y.Y, rev. AUD 1.97bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.68bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Scentre Group (SCG AT) - Co. H1 FFO AUD 676.2mln vs. Prev. AUD 657.2mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

South32 (S32 AT) - Co. FY19 underlying net AUD 992mln vs. Prev. AUD 1.33bln Y/Y, rev. AUD 7.27bln vs. Prev. AUD 7.55bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Southern Cross Media (SXL AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 76.2mln vs. Prev. AUD 73.9mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Spotless Group (SPO AT) - Co. FY19 net AUD 84.0mln vs. Prev. loss AUD 2.3mln Y/Y, rev. AUD 3.03bln vs. Prev. AUD 3.04bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Vocus Communications (VOC AT) - Co. FY19 underlying net fell 17% Y/Y to AUD 105.5mln, rev. AUD 1.89bln vs. Prev. AUD 1.88bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Japan Tobacco (2914 JT) - Co. July domestic cigarette sales volumes declined 5.5% Y/Y, while it gets approval from MoF to raise tobacco prices in October amid sales tax hike. (Newswires)

Sony (6758 JT) - Sony Pictures Entertainment is said to reach an impasse with Disney (DIS) on revenue sharing which threatens the Japanese group’s earnings for Spider-Man in which it holds the motion picture rights of the character. (Nikkei)

TEPCO (9501 JT) - Co. will widen home electricity sales to Tohoku and Kyushu. (Newswires)

Employment - Japan is to support employment of a million members of the so-called "lost generation," who graduated from high school or university into a serious job crunch after the collapse of the bubble economy in the early 1990s through hiring subsidies. (Nikkei)

Other News - Japan and South Korean Foreign Ministers met for talks in Beijing yesterday but failed to make any significant progress to resolve their ongoing issues. (Nikkei)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Geopolitics - North Korea said it is not interested in talks as long as military threats continue. (Yonhap)

Other News - South Korea reached a free trade agreement with Israel. (Yonhap)

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
FOMC MINUTES

FOMC Minutes stated that a couple of policymakers would have preferred a 50bps rate cut instead of a 25bps to address low inflation, although most saw a 25bps cut as part of a recalibration of policy stance or mid-cycle adjustment in response to recent outlook changes, while several policymakers favoured maintaining the same target rate at the July meeting. (Newswires)

Furthermore, the minutes stated policymakers generally preferred an approach that avoided any appearance of the Fed being on a preset course and that policymakers who favoured a rate cut noted a decelerating economy as well as elevated risks such as the global economic outlook, international trade and the US inflation outlook, while a few expressed concern over the persistent 3-month/10-year yield curve inversion.

Traders suggested the key from the minutes was the reference to the mid-cycle adjustment which suggests that Fed Chair Powell's use of the phrase was not an off-the-cuff remark at the post-meeting press conference. As such, traders said this would likely continue putting pressure on the 2s10s part of the curve, into inversion once again. In the wake of the minutes, Fed funds futures saw a 98% chance of a 25bps cut (vs 93% before the meeting) and money markets priced around 27bps of easing at the September meeting vs. around 30bps at the end of last week, markets priced 110bps of easing through the end of 2020 which is unchanged vs. end of last week.

 

ASIA-PAC

US President Trump reiterated the US will probably make a deal with China. In other news, senior officials said the US will soon go to China and meet officials "to hold them accountable" for fentanyl trafficking, while the officials added that China needs to do more which is the reason why they are going. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor Hu Xijin said China views the US threat to link trade talks with the Hong Kong situation with scorn and China is making arrangements on the scenario that a deal will not be reached. (Twitter)

China is to hold a public relations event in October to entice global investors turned off by the US-China trade war with Beijing to launch a big global multinational forum in Qingdao in October to show the world that China remains open for business. (SCMP)

China has threatened sanctions over the deal for the US to sell F-16 fighter aircraft to Taiwan. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau said he will defend Canada’s interests in China dispute and stated “we do not escalate, we also do not back down”, while he also urged dialogue and respect for fundamental freedoms in Hong Kong. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reiterated the UK wants a deal with the EU and believes the UK can get a deal but cannot accept the current withdrawal agreement, while he added we do need the backstop removed and can move forward if it is removed. Furthermore, PM Johnson replied there is scope to do a deal when asked if he would make any compromises. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said she would welcome a negotiated Brexit deal but is ready for all outcomes and challenged UK PM Johnson to come up with a solution to avert a no-deal Brexit in the next 30-days. Furthermore, Merkel stated that the European offer stands to negotiate a deal after Brexit as their goal is to continue having tight relations with Britain post Brexit, although there were also earlier comments from a Germany government spokesperson that preparations for a disorderly Brexit are being carried out with high energy. (Newswires)

French President Macron said he can't see a reason to grant a Brexit delay if there is no big change in the political situation such as an election or referendum, while he added that a re-negotiation of the Brexit deal on the terms provided by UK PM Johnson is not workable and that the US could not offset the cost of a no-deal for Britain. In related news, a French official said in view of UK PM Johnson's position on the Irish backstop, the baseline scenario now seems to be a no-deal Brexit and that the EU will consider the divorce bill to be due even in the case of a no-deal, while the official added the EU would probably accept to grant UK a delay on Brexit to hold new election. (Newswires)

 

FX

  • Canadian CPI (Jul) M/M 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.2%). (Newswires)
  • Canadian CPI (Jul) Y/Y 2.0% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 2.0%)

 

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks -2.73M vs. Exp. -1.89M (Prev. 1.58M). (Newswires)

DOE provided some details of the next SPR sale in which it stated that 10mln barrels are to be delivered from October to November. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS

French President Macron said he will hold talks with Iranian officials ahead of the G7 to make proposals and that he previously proposed some sanction relief or a compensation mechanism, while he added that in return for the offers, Iran must fully commit to the 2015 nuclear deal and broader negotiations on other issues. (Newswires)

Iran President Rouhani said international waterways will not have the same security as before if Iran oil exports are brought down to zero, while he added Iran have made a sound commitment to reduce commitments in the nuclear deal and will not accept others not delivering on their commitments. (Newswires)

Iran’s Foreign Minister Zarif said there were excellent discussions on issues of mutual interest and on ways to meaningfully preserve the nuclear pact with Swedish leaders. Zarif also commented that if Europe implements its part of the nuclear deal, Iran will then revert to it even if the US does not do so. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin said the US could deploy new land-based cruise missiles in Romania and later Poland, which is a threat to Russia, while he added Russia will take appropriate, reciprocal steps and are ready to talk with the US. (Newswires) 

 

US

US President Trump said he is not looking at indexing on capital gains nor at a payroll tax cut right now as the economy is strong and it is not needed, while he added that he looked at capital gains indexing and that it helps high income people but he would prefer to focus on the workers. (Newswires)

US President Trump reiterated his criticism on the Fed in which he alleged that they “totally missed the call” and raised rates "too fast and too furious", while he also stated that Germany is being paid to borrow money whilst they have zero interest, whereas the US is far stronger and is paying interest and just stopped quantitative tightening. (Twitter)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said the Fed should use forward guidance now and that he will argue for cuts at the September meeting, while he also suggested forward guidance can also provide stimulus by signalling overnight rates will be low in the future and argued for using forward guidance now before rates hit the lower bound as if a central bank cuts rates to zero in response to a downturn and then announces that it plans to keep rates low, that can actually be perceived as a sign of weakness rather than strength. Furthermore, Kashkari added that at a minimum, we should commit to not raising rates again until core inflation returns to our 2 per cent target on a sustained basis. (FT)

US CBO stated that US real GDP growth to slow to 2.3% this year (2.5% in 2018) due to falling business fixed investments, and that higher trade barriers will make GDP 0.3% smaller by 2020, while it sees US growth to average 1.8% between 2020 to 2023 and the budget deficit to reach USD 960bln this year (USD 63bln higher than the May estimate). (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

Target (TGT) and Lowe’s (LOW) reported solid earnings, both beating on top and bottom line; TGT raised FY EPS guidance and forecast SSS to increase 3.4% for FY19. LOW reported SSS +2.3% and affirmed its FY19 EPS guidance. The decent earnings boosted other retailers, with Kohl’s (KSS), Gap (GAP) and Nordstrom (JWN) among the outperformers in the SPX. On the flipside, Aflac (ALF) was an underperformer on reports it mis-sold insurance policies in Japan. Tesla (TSLA) was lower after reports it is being sued by Walmart (WMT) over allegedly failing to live up to industry standards in its installation of solar panels on top of hundreds of stores, which resulted in multiple fires across the US. Toll Brothers (TOL) fell despite earnings beat, with disappointing decline in unit orders. Alliance Data Systems (ADS) was higher after it announced its final results of its modified Dutch auction tender offer; roughly 12,100,000 shares of common stock were properly tendered and not properly withdrawn at or below the purchase price of USD 162.00 per share. S&P 500 0.8% AT 2924, NASDAQ-100 0.9% AT 7733, DOW JONES 0.9% AT 26204.

The Treasury curve flattened on Wednesday; major curve spreads were mixed/little changed in the early part of the session, as traders awaited the FOMC's July meeting minutes. In wake of the minutes, there was more modest flattening; the minutes themselves were mostly as expected, although it did make a reference to the 3-month/10-year part of the curve (policymakers concerned over the persistent inversion). Interestingly, the "mid-cycle adjustment" comment made its way into the minutes, suggesting it was not an off-the-cuff remark by Chair Powell at the July presser. The 2s10s part of the curve narrowed modestly in wake of the minutes, but at settlement, had just about avoided entering inversion again. Attention now shifts to Thursday's ECB minutes, survey data, and the start of the Jackson Hole conference, all ahead of the weekend's G7 meeting; traders will be looking to policymakers for clues about both monetary and fiscal policy easing (and any indication of a quasi-coordinated effort). US T-note futures (U9) settle 6+ ticks lower at 130-17.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 21st August 2019: Most FOMC participants back mid cycle adjustment stance, two voted for 50bps
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries lower, Dollar flat, Crude mixed
  • REAR VIEW: FOMC minutes back rate cut as mid cycle adjustment, Firm CAD CPI, BoJo & Merkel met to discuss the backstop
  • NEXT UP: Data: EZ & US Flash PMIs, US Initial Jobless Claims and EZ Consumer Confidence (Flash) Events: Fed’s Jackson Hole Symposium Begins, ECB Minutes & French President Macron meeting UK PM Johnson Earnings: Antofagasta, Salesforce.com, HP

 

* MARKETS WRAP: Markets traded tentative ahead of FOMC minutes which were uneventful for markets as many had predicted. Nonetheless, markets reversed from yesterday’s risk off tone amid no real catalyst, however some desks note Tuesday’s sell-off was driven by a lack of volume in the European market. Positive earnings from retailers Target (TGT) & Lowe’s (LOW) also added to positive sentiment at the open, showing even further signs consumers are still active after Walmart’s (WMT) stellar earnings report last week. Gains were capped post FOMC as the 2s10s curve briefly inverted once again. Now that the backward-looking FOMC minutes have been dispatched with, the market’s focus is on comments due from Fed Chair Powell on Friday, though Thursday’s ECB minutes and PMI data should contribute to the global growth theme. And after Powell, on the weekend’s G7 summit. And in wake of those events, traders will take stock of how global monetary and fiscal authorities will support growth, in perhaps a quasi-coordinated fashion. This week, desks have warned of risks of disappointment from these events, so the reaction in the early part of next week will be key in determining the tone of how risk assets will trade in the weeks’ ahead.

* FOMC MINUTES: Minutes for the July FOMC stated that a couple of policymakers would have preferred a 50bps rate cut instead of 25bps in order to address low inflation. Most saw a 25bps rate cut as part of a "recalibration" of its policy stance, or a mid-cycle adjustment, in response to the recent outlook changes. Of those who favoured a rate cut, they noted a decelerating economy, elevated risks on the global economy, trade risks, and the outlook for US inflation. Several favoured holding rates. Interestingly, the minutes revealed that policymakers pursued a policy approach that avoids giving the impression that the central bank is on a pre-set course. The key from the minutes, traders said, was that the phrase mid-cycle adjustment made an appearance in the release; that suggests that Fed Chair Powell's use of the phrase was not an off-the-cuff remark at the post-meeting press conference. As such, traders said this would likely continue putting pressure on the 2s10s part of the curve, into inversion once again. In wake of the minutes, Fed funds futures see a 98% chance of a 25bps cut (vs 93% before the meeting); for the September meeting specifically, money markets price around 27bps of easing at the September meeting (a 25bps rate cut remains fully priced) versus around 30bps at the end of last week; markets price 110bps of easing through the end of 2020 (unch vs end of last week).

* FED: San Francisco Fed President Daly late Tuesday penned a post where she said incoming economic data points to continued economic expansion, citing solid labour markets and consumer spending. Daly explained that her vote to cut rates in July was to counter economic headwinds, but not because she feared an imminent recession. She warned however, that a recession could become a self-fulfilling prophecy if headwinds from weaker global growth and trade uncertainties continue to linger. Fed’s Kashkari (non-voter, Dove) wrote an op-ed in the FT, pushing the argument that the Fed should implement forward guidance. Kashkari said the Fed should use forward guidance now, and that it can also provide stimulus by signalling that overnight rates will be low in the future. Kashkari made the point that it was better to use forward guidance now, before rates hit the lower bound, since if a central bank cuts rates to zero in response to a downturn and then announces that it plans to keep rates low, that can actually be perceived as a sign of weakness rather than strength. Kashkari said that, at minimum, the Fed should commit to not hiking again until core inflation reaches 2% on a sustainable basis. Elsewhere, Kashkari said he'd argue for rate cuts at the September FOMC.

* TRUMP: US President Trump largely reiterated remarks he has made recently; once again, he attacked the Fed, intimating that the central bank was holding back the economy. On the payrolls tax, he said he was not looking at cutting this tax right now, because the economy is strong, and does not need one. Analysts have suggested that Trump has shown signs of relenting recently. Recent instances of a potential Trump relent include: 1) a conference call between Trump and bank chiefs last week regarding the stock market on Wednesday, 2) Friday's Treasury announcement that it was mulling additional ultra-long issuance, and 3) this week's news that a payroll tax cut is being considered by the administration. UBS says that "while one can't be certain all of these came directly from Trump himself, it would certainly seem consistent with a Trump that is becoming increasingly anxious about the potential for an economic slowdown right ahead of elections." However, on the China front, UBS says that Trump is being politically rewarded for being hawkish, and therefore, we should not expect a capitulation on trade, with UBS arguing that he will instead rely on other levers first. Payroll tax cuts, however, do not seem likely to be one of those levers, UBS says, since they fund social security and Medicare, and the Democrats in the House would therefore likely oppose. But UBS says we should keep an eye out for other propositions in the coming weeks and months. "Ultimately the signs are increasing that the Trump put strike is approaching at-the-money," UBS says, "it may then follow then that the Fed may feel even less pressure to meet market expectations for a more aggressive path of rate cuts."

* 2019 CES PRELIMINARY BENCHMARK REVISION: The Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) announced its preliminary estimate of the upcoming annual benchmark revision to the establishment survey employment series; the update means that the US created 501k fewer jobs in the last year than was previously reported. The final benchmark revision will be issued in February 2020, with the publication of the January 2020 Employment Situation news release.

* US EXISTING HOME SALES: The July print rose from the prior revised 5.29mln to 5.42mln, beating expectations of 5.39mln. Pantheon Macroeconomics said the rise was not as large as implied by the June pending sales index, which pointed to a 5.55mln reading, although it is a step in the right direction, and points to a rise in sales in the early part of autumn. The inventory stood at 4.2months worth which equates to 1.89mln units; Pantheon said the inventories were stabilising and expect price gains to firm over the next few months too.

* CANADA CPI: Consumer prices rose to 2.0% Y/Y, above expectations for a deceleration to 1.7% from 2.0%; the M/M measure rose by 0.5% (prev. -0.2%), also beating expectations for 0.2%. Analysts at RBC noted that the increase in inflation is down to a surge in July airfares increasing 14% M/M, however, energy still accounted for a large portion of the gains, as energy prices rose 1.9% M/M following the prior months' decline. The three BoC measures averaged 2.03%, unchanged from the prior month and in line with BoC’s inflation target. RBC mentions that the odds of BoC entering an easing cycle like the Fed and other global central banks has recently intensified, with risks tilted to an earlier move than the 25bps cut in early 2020 which is pencilled in. RBC highlights this report did little to change the narrative that near-term price and economic growth trends still look too strong for the BoC to justify a rate cut immediately. Prior to the release markets were pricing in 26bps worth of easing by December, however following today’s inflation readings pricing has lowered to just shy of 25bp priced in by December, and 33.78bp by January 2020.

* BREXIT: Ahead of the meeting tomorrow between French President Macron and UK PM Johnson, a French official said that, in view of UK PM Johnson's position on the Irish backstop, the baseline scenario now seems to be a no-deal Brexit; even in the case of a no-deal, the EU will consider Brexit bill to be due. EU would probably accept to grant UK a delay on Brexit to hold new election, the official said, but added that the UK should have no doubt France, Germany and other EU countries are totally united, and that the EU will not cave it to pressure from US President Trump. Macron stated he can’t see a reason to grant a Brexit delay if there is no big change in the political situation, such as an election or referendum. He added, the renegotiation of Brexit deal on Johnson’s terms is not workable and that the US could not offset the cost of a no deal for Britain. UK PM Johnson’s meeting with German Chancellor Merkel has not yielded any meaningful Brexit breakthrough (at pixel time), despite some constructive remarks from Merkel on Tuesday (she called for practical solutions to be found on the backstop issue; though she did suggest that this should be in the framework of the political declaration, not the withdrawal agreement). In the press conference, she also mentioned she sees “possibilities” for a solution to the Irish backstop, but it would require hard work adding maybe we can find a solution in “maybe the next two years, maybe we can find it in the next 30 days”. Merkel and Johnson tended to reiterate familiar arguments at the press conference. Given the Johnson administration has already imposed a ‘red line’ (backstop must be jettisoned from the withdrawal agreement, or the UK/EU cannot reach a Brexit deal), the dial is once again little changed. Johnson will meet French President Macron on Thursday, ahead of his attendance at this weekend’s G7 meeting, and that meeting is probably worth paying more attention to, SocGen says, noting that President Macron has been the flag bearer with EU Council President Tusk for opposing new negotiations, and standing by 31st October as the firm and final deadline. Expectations for that Johnson/Macron meeting are low. Elsewhere, in domestic Brexit preparations, the UK Treasury announced it will automatically enrol 88k UK exporting companies in a key customs-tracking system, allowing trade with the EU to continue after 31st October, the date where the UK is scheduled to officially leave the EU.

* TAIWAN: China has threatened sanctions over the deal for the US to sell F-16 fighter aircraft to Taiwan, in an USD 8bln deal for 66 jets. Beijing regards Taiwan as part of its territory, and has regularly criticised US/Taiwan arms deals. China said it will take all necessary measures to safeguard its own interests.

* IRAN: Iranian President Rouhani said if Iran’s oil exports are brought down to zero, international waterways will not have the same security as before; reiterating that Iran has reduced commitments in the nuclear deal and will not accept others not delivering on theirs. However, Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif (a noted “dove” of the Iranian regime) said on Wednesday that he had held productive meetings with Scandinavian officials – including Sweden’s PM - on issues of mutual interest and on ways to meaningfully preserve the 2015 nuclear pact; earlier saying Iran would revert to the pact if Europe makes its commitments, even if the US does not. French President Macron later said he will hold talks with Iranian officials ahead of the G7 to make proposals, adding that he previously proposed some sanction relief or a compensation mechanism, but in return Iran must fully commit to the nuclear pact and broader negotiations on other issues. It was also reported on Wednesday that another US drone was shot down in the region on Tuesday - in Yemen - by the Houthi rebels, a group known to be backed by the Iranian Revolutionary Guard.

* TREASURIES: US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 6+ TICKS LOWER AT 130-17.

The Treasury curve flattened on Wednesday; major curve spreads were mixed/little changed in the early part of the session, as traders awaited the FOMC's July meeting minutes. In wake of the minutes, there was more modest flattening; the minutes themselves were mostly as expected, although it did make a reference to the 3-month/10-year part of the curve (policymakers concerned over the persistent inversion). Interestingly, the "mid-cycle adjustment" comment made its way into the minutes, suggesting it was not an off-the-cuff remark by Chair Powell at the July presser. The 2s10s part of the curve narrowed modestly in wake of the minutes, but at settlement, had just about avoided entering inversion again. Attention now shifts to Thursday's ECB minutes, survey data, and the start of the Jackson Hole conference, all ahead of the weekend's G7 meeting; traders will be looking to policymakers for clues about both monetary and fiscal policy easing (and any indication of a quasi-coordinated effort)

* WTI (V9) SETTLES USD 0.45 LOWER AT USD 55.68; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD 0.27 HIGHER AT USD 60.30.

Crude prices are lower on the day after a net bearish EIA report saw benchmarks decouple from the improved risk appetite. EIA reported crude stocks drawing 2.7mln bbls (less than the API reported -3.5mln, but larger than the expected -1.9mln), however the products were more bearish (distillates +2.6mln vs. exp. +0.3mln; gasoline +0.3mln vs. exp. +0.17mln), which saw a net build (crude + products) of 190k, and benchmarks consequentially headed lower through to settlement. Elsewhere in the EIA report, production remained unchanged at 12.3mln BPD; Cushing reported another large draw (-2.5mln bbls) amid the de-bottlenecking of supply out of the Permian Basin; refinery utilisation remained elevated (1.1% vs. exp. 0.1%) which will have been a factor in rising product stocks. Elsewhere, Canadian Trans Mountain announced it had re-started construction on the Trans Mountain expansion project, which will bring capacity to 890k BPD from 300k once complete.

*ITALY: After PM Conte resigned on Tuesday, the question of whether we will get an alternative Italian government, or whether Italians will go to the polls (October/November has been suggested as the ‘window’) remains unresolved. A coalition between PD and 5SM could be given a mandate to attempt to form a government in order to push through the Italian budget in the autumn, but desks are not ruling out the more market-unfriendly snap elections, where polling data highlights the possibility that populist Salvini’s Lega could win a majority.

*GEOPOLITICS: China has threatened sanctions over the deal for the US to sell F-16 fighter aircraft to Taiwan, in an USD 8bln deal for 66 jets. Beijing regards Taiwan as part of its territory, and has regularly criticised US/Taiwan arms deals. China said it will take all necessary measures to safeguard its own interests.

* CLOSING LEVELS: S&P 500 0.8% AT 2924, NASDAQ-100 0.9% AT 7733, DOW JONES 0.9% AT 26204.

* SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary 1.8%, Consumer Staples 0.3%, Energy 0.8%, Financials 0.5%, Health Care 0.8%, Industrials 0.7%, Information Technology 1.2%, Materials 0.5%, Telecommunication Services 0.4%, Utilities 0.7%.

* STOCK SPECIFICS: Target (TGT) and Lowe’s (LOW) reported solid earnings, both beating on top and bottom line; TGT raised FY EPS guidance and forecast SSS to increase 3.4% for FY19. LOW reported SSS +2.3% and affirmed its FY19 EPS guidance. The decent earnings boosted other retailers, with Kohl’s (KSS), Gap (GAP) and Nordstrom (JWN) among the outperformers in the SPX. On the flipside, Aflac (ALF) was an underperformer on reports it mis-sold insurance policies in Japan. Tesla (TSLA) was lower after reports it is being sued by Walmart (WMT) over allegedly failing to live up to industry standards in its installation of solar panels on top of hundreds of stores, which resulted in multiple fires across the US. Toll Brothers (TOL) fell despite earnings beat, with disappointing decline in unit orders. Alliance Data Systems (ADS) was higher after it announced its final results of its modified Dutch auction tender offer; roughly 12,100,000 shares of common stock were properly tendered and not properly withdrawn at or below the purchase price of USD 162.00 per share.

* FX WRAP:  DX pared mild losses post-FOMC minutes ahead of the Jackson Hole Symposium. CAD outperformed following firm CPI data however USDCAD pared back some of its gains as oil prices continued to slide post DOE inventories. EURUSD traded rangebound all day as EUR tracked the dollar ahead of key events and remained relatively resilient given ongoing Italian and Spanish politics. Havens (JPY, CHF) were lower on the day as risk sentiment took a turn from yesterday. EMFX: Amidst a general recovery mission vs the Buck, the Rand managed to overcome soft inflation data as it still remains within the SARB inflation band, and further justifies the recent rate cut. The CPI was also driven by softer transport prices which are not expected to repeat as petrol prices have been rising in August and also expected to in September. The Argentine Peso lagged again, and its Mexican rival was hampered by softer than forecast Mexican retail sales data and rather downbeat Banxico rhetoric, albeit still stronger against USD.

analysis_details: The Treasury curve flattened on Wednesday; major curve spreads were mixed/little changed in the early part of the session, as traders awaited the FOMC's July meeting minutes. In wake of the minutes, there was more modest flattening; the minutes themselves were mostly as expected, although it did make a reference to the 3-month/10-year part of the curve (policymakers concerned over the persistent inversion). Interestingly, the "mid-cycle adjustment" comment made its way into the minutes, suggesting it was not an off-the-cuff remark by Chair Powell at the July presser. The 2s10s part of the curve narrowed modestly in wake of the minutes, but at settlement, had just about avoided entering inversion again. Attention now shifts to Thursday's ECB minutes, survey data, and the start of the Jackson Hole conference, all ahead of the weekend's G7 meeting; traders will be looking to policymakers for clues about both monetary and fiscal policy easing (and any indication of a quasi-coordinated effort).

analysis_details: Crude prices are lower on the day after a net bearish EIA report saw benchmarks decouple from the improved risk appetite. EIA reported crude stocks drawing 2.7mln bbls (less than the API reported -3.5mln, but larger than the expected -1.9mln), however the products were more bearish (distillates +2.6mln vs. exp. +0.3mln; gasoline +0.3mln vs. exp. +0.17mln), which saw a net build (crude + products) of 190k, and benchmarks consequentially headed lower through to settlement. Elsewhere in the EIA report, production remained unchanged at 12.3mln BPD; Cushing reported another large draw (-2.5mln bbls) amid the de-bottlenecking of supply out of the Permian Basin; refinery utilisation remained elevated (1.1% vs. exp. 0.1%) which will have been a factor in rising product stocks. Elsewhere, Canadian Trans Mountain announced it had re-started construction on the Trans Mountain expansion project, which will bring capacity to 890k BPD from 300k once complete.

subject: Money markets price around 27bps of easing at the September meeting (a 25bps rate cut remains fully priced) versus around 30bps at the end of last week; markets price 110bps of easing through the end of 2020 (unch vs end of last week)

FOMC Minutes: A couple of policymakers would have preferred a 50bps rate cut instead of a 25bps to address low inflation; most saw a 25bps cut as part of a recalibration of policy stance, or mid-cycle adjustment, in response to recent outlook changes
content:
• Several policymakers favoured maintaining the same target rate at the July meeting
  • Policymakers generally preferred an approach that avoided any appearance of the Fed being on a preset course
  • Policymakers who favoured a rate cut noted a decelerating economy, elevated risks such as the global economic outlook, international trade and the US inflation outlook
  • A few policymakers expressed concern over the persistent 3-month/10-year yield curve inversion
analysis_details: The key from the minutes, traders said, was that the phrase mid-cycle adjustment made an appearence in the release; that suggests that Fed Chair Powell's use of the phrase was not an off-the-cuff remark at the post-meeting press conference. As such, traders said this would likely continue putting pressure on the 2s10s part of the curve, into inversion once again.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Loonie lifted by data, crude and broader risk rebound
content:
NOK/SEK/CAD/AUD/NZD

The Scandi Crowns are (aptly) sitting at the head of the major table amidst a robust recovery in risk appetite that is also feeding into crude and fuelling gains in the Norwegian Krona and Canadian Dollar especially. Hence, Eur/Nok has pulled-back sharply from 10.0000 again, and closer to 9.9200, while Usd/Cad is testing bids said to be sitting just under Monday’s low at 1.3250 vs 1.3251 after stronger than forecast Canadian inflation data that has trimmed the probability of a BoC cut for September to sub-20% from a whisker above 25% pre-release, accordingly and naturally. Similarly, the Aussie has crept closer to 0.6800 again vs its US counterpart and touched 1.0600 on the Kiwi cross due to relative near term policy outlooks/guidance from the RBA compared to the Fed and RBNZ. Note, Nzd/Usd continues to hover precariously above 0.6400.

GBP

More late drama for the Pound, but this time a bout of weakness prompted by French comments on Brexit that are broadly negative in contrast to Germany’s Merkel yesterday. In short, UK PM Johnson’s position on the Irish border backstop means that the base scenario now appears to be no deal, and even in that event the EU expects Britain to foot the bill for leaving. Cable retreated further from near 1.2200 in response, but is holding just above 1.2100 and the 10 DMA (1.2103) awaiting tonight’s dinner date between Johnson and Merkel, ahead of his meeting with France’s Macron on Thursday that looks set to be less cordial. Back to Sterling, Eur/Gbp has rebounded through 0.9150 and from a technical perspective could also test a DMA that resides up at 0.9208 and aligns with a Fib retracement level (vs the 30 DMA down at 0.9105).

CHF/JPY/EUR

Somewhat mixed fortunes for the non-US Dollar safe-havens as the Franc and Yen traded mostly weaker around 106.50 and 0.9800 respectively, but the single currency continued to pivot 1.1100 (like Gold on the Usd1500/oz axis) amidst the upturn in risk sentiment noted above. The Euro remains resilient (if not complacent) to potential heightened political upheaval on the Eurozone margins via Italy and Spain, or simply tracked muted moves in the Greenback pre-FOMC minutes as the DXY meandered rather aimlessly between 98.139-302.

EM

Amidst a general recovery mission vs the Buck, the Rand managed to overcome soft and SARB rate cut inducive SA inflation data on the premise that sub-target CPI is good for the economy as a whole, but the Argentine Peso lagged again and its Mexican rival was hampered by softer than forecast Mexican retail sales data and rather downbeat Banxico rhetoric.

subject: ANALYSIS: Plunging profit margins are a bad omen for the US economy, Oxford Economics says, but US consumers will continue to propel economic growth
content:
• US corporate profits have printed their first back-to-back quarterly decline in two years, and profit margins have endured their longest late-cycle contraction in post-war history, a worrisome sign, Oxford Economics says. Newly revised NIPA data also suggests that the strong profits previously reported were due to aggressive financial accounting, and underestimations of employee stock options exercised, the economic consultancy notes.
  • "Stronger revenues and faster productivity growth have buffered companies’ profitability in recent years," OxEco writes, "however, with global growth slowing sharply, and domestic activity cooling, further profit weakness represents a risk for business investment and hiring – a key support to consumer spending."
  • OxEco says that while declining profit margins are a reliable leading recession indicator, lead times in the post-war era have varied greatly – from 12 months to four years. "Further, long economic expansions have typically been accompanied by prolonged margin contractions, as was the case in the late 1990s, and increased Fed dovishness should provide a buffer."
  • It says that, encouragingly, the post-NIPA revision profit clouds came with two silver linings: 1) the late-cycle compression in margins has limited inflationary pressures, thereby allowing the Fed to embark on an easing cycle, and 2) the downshift in profits was offset by sizeable upward revisions to compensation, suggesting that US consumers will continue to propel economic growth.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Slips but Ranges Hold ahead of Fed Minutes
content:
•   USD mixed vs majors as quiet trade persists; focus on FOMC minutes today.
  •   CAD firmer ahead of CPI as crude gains; USDCAD well-capped in mid-1.33s.
  •   EUR steady despite Italian politics; gains should extend through 1.1110.
  •   GBP retains a soft undertone; budget data weak and Brexit worries persist.
  •   JPY slips as European stocks rally but downside likely limited in near term.
  •   AUD remains in consolidation range below 0.68.

subject: Germany government spokesperson says preparations for disorderly Brexit are being carried out with high energy
analysis_details:
• UK PM Johnson’s meeting with German Chancellor Merkel this evening is not expected to yield any meaningful Brexit breakthrough, despite some constructive remarks from Merkel on Tuesday (she called for practical solutions to be found on the backstop issue; though she did suggest that this should be in the framework of the political declaration, not the withdrawal agreement). 
  • Given the Johnson administration has already imposed a ‘red line’ (backstop must be jettisoned from the withdrawal agreement, or the UK/EU cannot reach a Brexit deal), the dial is once again little changed. 
  • Johnson will meet French President Macron on Thursday, ahead of his attendance at this weekend’s G7 meeting, and that meeting is probably worth paying more attention to, SocGen says, noting that President Macron has been the flag bearer with EU Council President Tusk for opposing new negotiations, and standing by 31st October as the firm and final deadline.
  • Expectations for that Johnson/Macron meeting are also low.

  • Foreign Minister Zarif says if Europe implements its part of the nuclear deal Iran will then revert to it even if the US does not do so

subject: ANALYSIS: Trump has shown signs of relenting, but will not do so on trade, UBS says; watch out for additional Trump measures ahead
content:
• Recent instances of a potential Trump relent include: 1) a conference call between Trump and bank chiefs last week regarding the stock market on Wednesday, 2) Friday's Treasury announcement that it was mulling additional ultra-long issuance, and 3) this week's news that a payroll tax cut is being considered by the administration.
  • UBS says that "while one can't be certain all of these came directly from Trump himself, it would be certainly seem consistent with a Trump that is becoming increasingly anxious about the potential for an economic slowdown right ahead of elections."
  • However, on the China front, UBS says that Trump is being politically rewarded for being hawkish, and therefore, we should not expect a capitulation on trade, with UBS arguing that he will instead rely on other levers first. Payroll tax cuts, however, do not seem likely to be one of those levers, UBS says, since they fund social security and Medicare, and the Democrats in the House would therefore likely oppose.
  • But UBS says we should keep an eye out for other propositions in the coming weeks and months. "Ultimately the signs are increasing that the Trump put strike is approaching at-the-money," UBS says, "it may then follow then that the Fed may feel even less pressure to meet market expectations for a more aggressive path of rate cuts."

subject: Rosneft notifies buyers that future tender contracts will be in EUR, not in USD, as early as this year, multiple sources say
content: • The move is likley to be seen as an attempt to offset any potential negative impact of US sanctions on Russia, the report noted.
analysis_details:
• NOTE: Russia accounts for 40% of Russian oil output; top customers include BP (BP LN), Glencore (GLEN LN), Trafigura, Vitol and Cetracore
  • Rosneft earlier this month asked buyers to use the EUR as the currency of exchange in spot tenders to sell naphtha

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 21st August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices are firmer this morning as risk sentiment recovers somewhat, to the detriment of fixed income and safe havens
  • Fed’s Daly stated she does not think we are heading for a recession while Fed’s Kashkari believes Fed should use forward guidance now and will argue for cuts in September
  • USD is mixed vs. G10 counterparts though is outperforming safe havens on sentiment and Sterling ahead of UK PM Johnson's meeting with German Chancellor Merkel
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI, US Existing Home Sales, FOMC & RBI Minutes

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded subdued as the region conformed to the dampened global risk tone with markets cautious ahead of the looming FOMC minutes and the Jackson Hole Symposium. ASX 200 (-1.0%) underperformed with broad pressure across its sectors. Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) was also lower but with downside stemmed as exporters found some solace from a gradually weakening currency, while Hang Seng (+0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) traded indecisively after the PBoC’s quasi liquidity efforts resulted to another net daily drain and amid ongoing trade uncertainty as US President reiterated he is currently not ready to make a trade deal with China but suggested something will happen maybe sooner later. In addition, reports noted that outflows from funds focused on China investments recently widened to its highest since early 2017. Finally, 10yr JGBs returned flat as the initial upside from the cautious risk tone later faded after hitting resistance at the 155.00 level and near its record highs, while the BoJ were only in the market today for Treasury Discount Bills.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0433 vs. Exp. 7.0468 (Prev. 7.0454)

US Secretary of State Pompeo was said to sound bullish regarding the prospect of trade deal and thinks a US-China deal could be reached by the 2020 election. (Newswires)

The US and Japan are rushing to clear the final hurdles on the way to a partial trade deal that could be finalised as early as September. Japan’s Economy Minister Motegi and USTR will meet in Washington for crunch talks today, according to sources. (FT)

Investors withdrew USD 2.9bln from funds focused on China investment in the month to August 14th which is the largest outflows of its kind in more than 2 years. (FT)

Reports note that out of 14 listed Chinese banks that have reported H1 results, 11 recorded net profit increases of at least 10%. (Newswires)

US

US President Trump postponed a meeting with Denmark PM Frederiksen due to her refusal to discuss purchase of Greenland, while he added the PM was able to save a great deal of expense and effort for both sided by being so direct and that he looks forward to rescheduling sometime in the future. (Twitter)

Fed's Daly (non-voter, dove) said she sees solid domestic momentum that points to a continued economic expansion, while Daly added she doesn’t think were headed to a recession and her support for a cut last month did not reflect concern about an economic downturn. (Newswires).

Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, Dove) says the Fed should use forward guidance now; will argue for cuts at the September meeting, Argues for using forward guidance now, before rates hit the lower bound. At a minimum, we should commit to not raising rates again until core inflation returns to our 2 per cent target on a sustained basis. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

US Special Envoy for North Korea Biegun said US is prepared to restart discussions as soon as North Korea are ready. In related news, a Japanese defence report noted that North Korea has already achieved miniaturization of a nuclear warhead, while there were separate comments from US Marines Commandant Berger that US, Japan and South Korea share common view of North Korea threat, as well as China's long-term threat to stability. (Newswires)

China's Foreign Ministry, when asked about UK Consulate worker in Hong Kong, says the worker is under administrative detention in China for violation of Chinese law. (Newswires)

Venezuela President Maduro said he had authorized secret meetings for months between top officials and the Trump administration. (Newswires)

Japan's Foreign Minister Kono discussed military intelligence pact with South Korea, adds that Japan wants to maintain pact. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif says no amount of foreign military presence can prevent insecurity in the Gulf, adds its possible to agree on confidence building measures to ensure freedom of navigation in the Gulf. And if Europe implements its part of the nuclear deal Iran will then revert to it even if the US does not do so. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson will tell German Chancellor Merkel today that Parliament cannot stop Britain leaving the EU without a deal on October 31. (Times)

German Senior Conservative Roettgen notes that rhetoric from the UK does not change Germany's position on Brexit, there is no room to amend the Withdrawal Agreement as long as there is no solution to the Irish Border problem. (Newswires)

Italy's main opposition PD party is to give its leader Zingaretti the mandate to form a new government, according to a spokesperson. (Newswires) For reference, recent polls indicate that PD are the 2nd largest party in Italy, behind Salvini’s League with 5-Star in 3rd position.

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +1.2%] despite a subdued Asia-Pac handover with some citing a possible market squeeze. Market participants note that stocks are driven by a couple factors: 1) Today’s session commenced at a low base as stocks yesterday were pressured by Italian concerns. 2) low volumes heading into key risk events including FOMC/ECB Minutes (full previews available in the Research Suite) and the annual Jackson Hole Symposium, US volumes have also been low. Sectors are all in the green, with underperformance seen in defensive stocks as investors seek riskier equities. Consumer discretionary is the marked outperformer with gains led by Pandora (+13.6%) as its earning-led optimism continues, whilst Fiat Chrysler (+3.5%) and Renault (+4.9%) shares rebounded amid reports on continuing merger talks. In terms of other individual movers, GEA group (+5.1%) rests closer to the top of the Stoxx 600. On the flip side, Alcon (-2.5%) shares fell following earnings after-hours yesterday.

Apple (AAPL) is reportedly in final stages of certifying advanced screens from China's BOE Technology Group for next year's iPhones, thus reducing its reliance on Samsung Electronics (005930 KS), Nikkei reports.

Lowe's Companies Inc (LOW) Q2 19 (USD): EPS 2.15 (exp. 2.00), Revenue 21bln (exp. 20.97bln). Same Store Sales +2.3% (exp. 1.7%). (Newswires)

Target Corp (TGT) Q2 19 (USD): EPS 1.82 (exp. 1.62), Revenue 18.4bln (exp. 18.32bln). Raises FY EPS guidance by 0.15.

FX

USD - The Greenback has waned again, with the DXY fading just ahead of 98.500 and the more significant pinnacle reached at the start of the month when the index scaled fresh ytd highs (98.932). Usd/major pairings remain relatively mixed and rangebound in advance of potentially market-moving and game-changing events to come in the form of FOMC minutes, preliminary PMIs, ECB minutes and then the JC gathering that kicks off tomorrow and runs through to Saturday. In the interim, US existing home sales may provide some impetus as the DXY meanders between 98.302-145.

JPY/NZD/CHF/GBP - Another upturn in broad risk sentiment has pushed the safe-haven Yen, Franc and Gold back down from yesterday’s peaks towards 106.60, through 0.9800 and 1500 respectively, but the Kiwi and Pound have also lost ground against the Buck, with Nzd/Usd retesting 0.6400 and Cable retreating from circa 1.2175 to 1.2130. Note, technical resistance at the 21 DMA (1.2172) and ahead of 1.2200 (1.2197 Fib retracement) could have stymied Sterling again along with more clarification from EU officials that any alternatives to the Irish backstop would be facilitated via the PD not the WA.

AUD/CAD/EUR - The G10 outperformers, or at least holding up better than the rest as the Aussie retains sight of the 0.6800 handle, Loonie pivots 1.3300 and Euro continues to straddle 1.1100, awaiting aforementioned highlights for the week (on paper at least). Aud/Usd remains supported in wake of RBA minutes underlining a wait-and-see approach after recent rate cuts, while Usd/Cad has retreated from Tuesday’s apex amidst a rebound in crude prices and looking for further direction from Canadian CPI data and the single currency is still showing resilience in the face of Eurozone political instability in Italy and Spain.

NOK/SEK - The Scandi Crowns are benefiting from the latest revival in risk appetite and Eur/Nok has topped out ahead of 10.0000 despite weaker than forecast Norwegian unemployment, while Eur/Sek is drifting down from 10.7600+ towards 10.7100 in tandem.

EM - A generally firmer tone across the region, with the Rand drawing encouragement from soft SA inflation even though this may prompt more SARB easing, as Usd/Zar breached key chart support around 15.2800 to probe under 15.2200 before returning to 15.2500 and consolidating.

FX Option Expiries of Note:

- EUR/USD 1.1140 (416M), 1.1150-60 (1.04BLN), 1.1245-50 (1.5BLN)

- USD/JPY 105.50 (575M), 105.70-84 (1.6BLN), 106.00 (900M), 106.75 (775M)

 

FIXED

Bunds and Gilts have recovered well from tests of technical support levels ahead of 178.00 and 134.00 respectively to revisit earlier Eurex and Liffe intraday highs, with the former seemingly disregarding the new 30 year German offering that was shunned by all but a minority not deterred with the discount against coupon. Or maybe the 10 year debt future has actually benefited from curve displacement and long end underperformance via curve re-positioning in wake of the 2050 launch? Meanwhile, US Treasuries remain weak and the curve steeper albeit off overnight extremes in outright and spread terms, largely shrugging off loud policy calls from Fed uber-dove Kashkari ahead of FOMC minutes and housing data.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent prices are firmer amid the improvement in risk appetite coupled with support from a larger-than-forecast drawdown in API crude stocks (-3.5mln vs. Exp. -1.9mln). Elsewhere, reports stated that Canada’s Alberta has decided to extend it current production curbs by a year, until the end of 2020 amid slow pipeline progress. Due to the extension, the base limit will increase to 20k BPD from 10k BPD per producers (effective Oct 1st), thus helping out the smaller producers as the first 20k BPD of production will be exempt from cuts. Turning to geopolitics where Fox News, citing sources, reported that an Iranian oil tanker (Bonita Queen) is heading to Syria and carrying around 600k barrels of crude, which would violate Western Sanctions. This comes just days after Iranian tanker Adrian Darya 1 (formerly Grace 1) was released from Gibraltar after being seized regarding suspected exports to Syria. On today’s docket, participants will be eyeing the widely followed weekly DoE inventory data for an immediate catalyst ahead of the FOMC minutes, with headline crude expected to drawdown of 1.889mln. Elsewhere, gold is lacklustre and trades around the 1500/oz mark amid a seemingly improved risk tone and some potential profit taking ahead of the FOMC minutes later. Meanwhile copper moves in tandem with the current risk sentiment and trades higher on the day, albeit prices remain below 2.6/lb. Finally, Dalian iron ore futures declined to 10-week lows amid the ongoing supply/demand imbalance, with traders citing further downside in light of BHP’s bleak outlook for the base metal.

Canada's Alberta extended oil production curtailments through to end-2020 due to slow pipeline progress and raised the limit from 10k bpd to 20k bpd per producer. (Newswires)

Polish Central Banker Ancyparowicz says there is no need for monetary policy easing right now
Fed's Kashkari (non-voter, Dove) says the Fed should use forward guidance now; will argue for cuts at the September meeting
content:
Via FT

  • Argues forward guidance can also provide stimulus by signalling that overnight rates will be low in the future.
  • Argues for using forward guidance now, before rates hit the lower bound, as if a central bank cuts rates to zero in response to a downturn and then announces that it plans to keep rates low, that can actually be perceived as a sign of weakness rather than strength.
  • Says at a minimum, we should commit to not raising rates again until core inflation returns to our 2 per cent target on a sustained basis.
  • Says although the Fed didn’t realise it at the time, by sending a message suggesting rate increases, this forward guidance was contractionary rather than stimulative, and argues that this is one of the reasons why the Fed has consistently overestimated the speed of inflation’s return to that target

subject: ANALYSIS: Nomura quants say markets have finished pricing in stimulus, now waiting for Powell
content:
• Nomura says that recent equity sentiment deterioration has been cushioned by hints of both monetary and fiscal stimulus ("wishful thinking", the bank describes it as); And after the global equity rebound paused on Tuesday, Nomura says participants appear to have finished pricing in media speculation regarding stimulus measures (fiscal outlays in Germany, tax cuts in the US) and are now waiting for Fed Chair Powell at Jackson Hole.
  • The bank takes note of the relative sentiment in equities vs bonds. It says that the improvement in bond sentiment has been sluggish compared to equities, and bond investors remain cautious. "It is hard to tell which set of investors is predicting the future direction of the overall market most accurately," Nomura writes, "when compared with economic momentum (combining sentiment indices for Europe, the US, and China), however, (1) equity investors' sentiment tends to overshoot on the optimistic side, while (2) bond investors' sentiment tends to track economic momentum more closely."
  • Nomura says the correlation between bond and equity sentiment has declined since the rise of political uncertainty under the Trump administration. The pricing function in equity markets needs to incorporate information other than macroeconomic indicators, which makes equity market sentiment inherently susceptible to divergence from actual economic conditions toward excessive optimism. "If expectations for stimulus measures to boost economic momentum end in disappointment, the gap between equity sentiment and bond sentiment could narrow once again."
  • The bank says that investors are on watch for a rise in bond volatility at present. "However, this appears to be heavily based on buyers pushing up volatility in a flight to quality in the bond markets, a situation we ascribe to concerns about a global economic slowdown manifesting in an undercurrent of panic buying."
  • The bank says it is hearing a lot from clients about higher bond volatility leading to bond sell-offs by CTAs, risk-parity funds, and other systematic players; However, Nomura thinks this rationale is flawed. "We think it likely that the strong performance of systematic players since the start of the year is owing to bond long positions for both CTAs and risk-parity funds. At the same time, market participants are likely raising their leverage on bond positions, such that any sudden sharp market swing would tend to occasion a surge in position risk."
  • But Nomura notes that risk-parity funds and CTAs have not turned net sellers of bonds to any large extent. "First, risk-parity funds aim to maintain overall portfolio risk at a certain level.
  • The bank notes that risk parity funds allocate on a systematic basis, with the funds not only taking into account the absolute level of bond volatility, but also volaility across all asset classes. As a result, risk-parity funds will not necessarily rush to deleverage risk across their entire portfolios if stock prices and bond prices maintain their diametric relationship as typical in the past, and when equity and commodity volatility are also rising, as at present. Additionally, trend-following CTAs continue to add longs in bond futures of major sovereign bonds. "Rising bond volatility is acting as a cap on CTAs' leverage, but with conspicuous upward momentum in futures for various sovereign bonds, we think CTAs are choosing to hold to a course of moderate net purchasing," Nomura says.

subject: ANALYSIS: Mattarella’s Decision
content:
*THE LATEST: Acting PM Conte handed in his resignation to President Mattarella yesterday as expected. President Mattarella will now begin talks with Parliamentary groups in search of a new coalition. If a new coalition is not formed, Italy could see the appointment a technocratic government with the goal of passing the Autumn 2020 budget in order to avoid an automatic 3% VAT tax hike. Failing that, the President will have to dissolve Parliament three and a half years ahead of schedule to pave the way for a general election in October or November.

*CARETAKER GOVERNMENT: President Mattarella has already approached Conte to remain as caretaker PM. Citi sees two possible governments of scope:

  • Technocratic Government – A group with a set goal to pass the Autumn 2020 budget to avoid a tax hike.
  • 5SM-led Government – Supported by PD and other MPs. This scenario seems less likely given the political difference between the 5SM and PD. Citi adds that such a coalition will not bode well with voters.

*ELECTIONS: League Leader Salvini said he will not resign and will remain as Interior Minister, while he will ask President Mattarella for early elections and stated there is no plan B besides an early vote. The timing of an election is subject to the Parliamentary reform which aims for a reduction in MPs (see schedule below), which HSBC says would mean elections could not take place for another five to six months at least, due to the need to allow a possible referendum to be called, and to re-draw the electoral boundaries. Analysts at ING believe that an election remain the most likely option: “The possibility of new elections and the threat of an extended period of political uncertainty continues to hint at downside risks for the Euro, alongside the possible dampening effect of the ECB's easing package to be delivered in September”, it said.

*LATEST POLLING: Comparing the 2018 general election results to current polls: League currently leads polls at 37% (it currently has 17.4% of the seats in the Lower House), PD follows in the polls with 23% (vs current 18.8%) and 5SM with 18% (vs current 32.7%). In terms of the smaller parties, Brothers of Italy poll at 7% (vs 4.4% in Parliament) and Forza Italia is polling at 6% (vs. current 14%)

*SCHEDULE:

  • 21st AUG - The President will begin consultation with minor groups at 1500 BST/1000 ET.
  • 22nd AUG - Mattarella is expected to hold talks with the main parties, concluding with the 5SM at 1600 BST/1100 ET. Tomorrow will also see the Lower House’ vote on the Fraccaro law, i.e. the proposal to see the number of MPs in both houses cut from 945 to 600. The approval of the law will prevent Italy from having elections until at least June 2020, Citi says. Last week, Deputy PM Salvini proposed accepting 5SM's demand for a parliamentary reform in return for swift elections
  • 26th AUG – The last day to appoint an Italian European Commissioner. Analysts note that without a government, the League could find it difficult to appoint one of their own in a key position within the European Commission. Thus, Citi notes that the League may end up even more isolated in Europe.
  • 27th SEP – Parliament starts reviewing budget law for 2020
  • 15th OCT – 2020 Budget has to be submitted to the European Commission
  • 20th OCT – 2020 Budget goes to the Italian Parliament

*RATING AGENCIES:

  •  6th SEP – Moody’s to review Italy’s credit rating
  • 25th OCT – S&P to review Italy’s credit rating

content:

  • Asian equity markets traded subdued as the region conformed to the dampened global risk tone with markets cautious ahead of looming FOMC risk
  • EU sources reportedly believe UK PM Johnson is pulling British officials out of EU meetings which hints that the PM is not serious about achieving a Brexit deal
  • Italian PM Conte submitted his resignation to Italian President Mattarella. Conte was then asked by President Mattarella to stay as a caretaker leader
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Canadian CPI, US Existing Home Sales, FOMC & RBI Minutes, German EUR 2.0bln 0.0% 2050 auction
  • Earnings: Lowe’s Companies, Target Corp & Analog Devices

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded subdued as the region conformed to the dampened global risk tone with markets cautious ahead of the looming FOMC minutes and the Jackson Hole Symposium. ASX 200 (-1.2%) underperformed with broad pressure across its sectors. Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) was also lower but with downside stemmed as exporters found some solace from a gradually weakening currency, while Hang Seng (Unch.) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) traded indecisively after the PBoC’s quasi liquidity efforts resulted to another net daily drain and amid ongoing trade uncertainty as US President reiterated he is currently not ready to make a trade deal with China but suggested something will happen maybe sooner later. In addition, reports noted that outflows from funds focused on China investments recently widened to its highest since early 2017. Finally, 10yr JGBs returned flat as the initial upside from the cautious risk tone later faded after hitting resistance at the 155.00 level and near its record highs, while the BoJ were only in the market today for Treasury Discount Bills.

 

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a net daily drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0433 vs. Exp. 7.0468 (Prev. 7.0454)

 

US President Trump reiterated that China wants to make a trade deal and something will happen maybe sooner or later, while he also reiterated he is currently not ready to make a trade deal with China and stated that someone had to take China on whether it was good or bad for the US in the short term. US Secretary of State Pompeo was said to sound bullish regarding the prospect of trade deal and thinks a US-China deal could be reached by the 2020 election. (Newswires)

 

The US and Japan are rushing to clear the final hurdles on the way to a partial trade deal that could be finalised as early as September. Japan’s Economy Minister Motegi and USTR will meet in Washington for crunch talks today, according to sources. (FT)

 

Investors withdrew USD 2.9bln from funds focused on China investment in the month to August 14th which is the largest outflows of its kind in more than 2 years. (FT)

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson said we will come up with solutions for Irish border during trade negotiations the EU, while he added the EU clearly still thinks there is a possibility that Parliament will block Brexit and are being a bit negative although he thinks we will get there. (Newswires)

EU sources reportedly believe UK PM Johnson is pulling British officials out of EU meetings which hints that the PM is not serious about achieving a Brexit deal, according to Express' Brussels Correspondent. (Twitter/Express)

UK PM Johnson will tell German Chancellor Merkel today that Parliament cannot stop Britain leaving the EU without a deal on October 31. (Times)

UK reportedly could delay a decision on the BoE Governor until Brexit is completed with sources also stating that if a general election is called the budget could be delayed until 2020. (Newswires)

Italy's League withdrew its no confidence motion against PM Conte who later submitted his resignation to Italian President Mattarella as expected, while PM Conte was then asked by President Mattarella to stay as a caretaker leader. League Leader Salvini said he will not resign and will remain as interior minister, while he will ask President Mattarella for early elections and stated there is no plan B besides an early vote. Italian President Mattarella will begin consulting on the next steps for Italian politics at 1500BST, discussions with the larger parties in Italy are due to take place on Thursday. (Newswires)

FX

DXY was lacklustre after the prior day’s losses although remained above 98.00 with downside limited as participants await the latest clues from the Fed beginning with today’s FOMC minutes and Fed Chair Powell’s remarks on Friday. A non-committal tone was also observed by the greenback’s major counterparts with EUR/USD contained just below 1.1100 amid political uncertainty in the bloc’s periphery in which Italy PM Conte submitted his resignation following the breakdown of the ruling coalition, and after Spain’s acting PM Sanchez failed in his first attempt to form a new government amid differences between his Socialists and the Podemos party. GBP/USD was quiet and held on to the recent gains spurred by comments from German Chancellor Merkel regarding practical solutions to the backstop and reports that some in the EU are said to have hinted at concessions on the backstop in back channels, although the upward momentum has dissipated as Merkel also noted her comments concerned the political declaration on future ties not the WA and as sides continued to point the finger of blame at each other. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses rebounded on a resumption of this week’s price swings, while antipodeans were choppy with support following a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting, counterbalanced by their high beta properties. 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures slightly higher and back above the USD 56.00/bbl level after the prior day’s choppy price action, with marginal gains seen following a larger than expected draw in the latest headline API crude inventories and reports Alberta extended its output curtailments for another year but doubled the daily limit per producer. Elsewhere, gold was lacklustre with price action tentative ahead of the FOMC minutes and copper prices also languished alongside the cautious risk tone, as well as weakness in Chinese commodity prices in which benchmark Chinese iron ore prices slumped more than 4% to a 10-week low shortly after the open. 

API Crude Inventories -3.5mln bbls vs. Exp. -1.9mln bbls (Prev. +3.7mln bbls). (Newswires)

Canada's Alberta extended oil production curtailments through to end-2020 due to slow pipeline progress and raised the limit from 10k bpd to 20k bpd per producer. (Newswires)

An oil tanker, The Bonita Queen, carrying 600k barrels of Iranian oil is headed to Syria, which would violate Western sanctions, according to sources cited by Fox. (Fox News)

GEOPOLITICS

US Special Envoy for North Korea Biegun said US is prepared to restart discussions as soon as North Korea are ready. In related news, a Japanese defence report noted that North Korea has already achieved miniaturization of a nuclear warhead, while there were separate comments from US Marines Commandant Berger that US, Japan and South Korea share common view of North Korea threat, as well as China's long-term threat to stability. (Newswires)

Venezuela President Maduro said he had authorized secret meetings for months between top officials and the Trump administration. (Newswires)

US

The TPLEX moved higher on an illiquid August Tuesday as risk appetite faded, with participants tentative ahead of key risk events later this week, namely Fed Chair Powell’s remarks at Jackson Hole. The move higher was predominantly in the European session, and exacerbated by some chunky block buys, with the having bull flattened by settlement; the 10-year yield fell 5bps whilst the 2-year yield fell 3bps, leaving the curve approximately 2bps flatter. US T-note future (U9) settled 9+ticks higher at 130-23+.

US President Trump reiterated that the Fed needs to be proactive and cut interest rates, while he added that the administration is looking at possible tax cuts and that the US is very far from a recession. Furthermore, Trump added he is not thinking about doing anything at this moment on tax cuts but it is something he is considering and White House Deputy Press Secretary Gidley also stated that President Trump is mulling all options for tax cuts. (Newswires)

US President Trump postponed a meeting with Denmark PM Frederiksen due to her refusal to discuss purchase of Greenland, while he added the PM was able to save a great deal of expense and effort for both sided by being so direct and that he looks forward to rescheduling sometime in the future. (Twitter)

Fed's Daly (non-voter, dove) said she sees solid domestic momentum that points to a continued economic expansion, while Daly added she doesn’t think were headed to a recession and her support for a cut last month did not reflect concern about an economic downturn. (Newswires).

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia conforms to the cautious global risk tone as market await Fed clues
content:
Asia equity markets trade subdued with the region conforming to the dampened global risk tone as markets turn cautious ahead of the looming FOMC minutes and the Jackson Hole Symposium, which saw Wall St. snap a 3-day win streak. ASX 200 (-1.0%) underperforms with broad losses seen across its sectors and with heavy losses seen in Iluka Resources, Stockland and WorleyParsons post-earnings, although APA Group and Seven Group Holdings are at the other end of the spectrum due to better FY results. Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) is also lower but off worse levels as exporters find some solace from a gradually weakening currency, while Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) are indecisive after the PBoC’s quasi liquidity efforts resulted to another net daily drain and amid ongoing trade uncertainty as US President reiterated he is currently not ready to make a trade deal with China but also suggested something will happen maybe sooner or maybe later.                                                                                                                                                                                                        

In FX markets, DXY is lacklustre after the prior day’s losses although remains above the 98.00 level with downside limited as participants await the latest clues from the Fed beginning with today’s FOMC minutes and Fed Chair Powell’s remarks on Friday. In addition, a non-committal tone is also seen in the greenback’s major counterparts with EUR/USD contained just below the 1.1100 handle amid political uncertainty in the bloc’s periphery in which Italy PM Conte submitted his resignation following the breakdown of the ruling coalition and after acting Spanish PM Sanchez failed in his first attempt to form a new government amid differences between his Socialists and the Podemos party. GBP/USD is quiet as it holds on to the recent gains spurred by comments from German Chancellor Merkel regarding practical solutions to the backstop and reports that some in the EU are said to have hinted at concessions on the backstop in back channels, although the upward momentum has dissipated as Merkel noted her comments concerned the political declaration on future ties not the withdrawal agreement and as sides continue to point the finger of blame at each other. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY-crosses rebound on a resumption of this week’s price swings, while antipodeans are choppy as support following a firmer than expected PBoC reference rate setting is counterbalanced by their high beta properties.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with initial upside from the cautious risk tone later faded after hitting resistance at the 155.00 level and near its record highs, with the BoJ only in the market today for Treasury Discount Bills.
